text: oh wow... #gsoc!
@Nishanth Menon Do you use the standard beagleplay config when buidling mainline? Do I need to copy the `firmware` from ti kernel?
i only use upstream defconfig
if there are patches missing in defconfig in upstream, I post it there
why do you need firmware? you are working on kernel. everything about firmware comes from beagle's build
I think robert even releases an upstream based disk image if you want to play around (I dont use it though. i just use the standard beagle images and replace the kernel
I remember it complaining at me when I was using config from beagleplay /boot/config.
we dont use beagle's config in upstream ðŸ˜‰ - the only big thing that is missing is containers - beagle customizes to enable docker - upstream is independent of a specific container tech..
tech..

@Nishanth Menon I have created a work branch (https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/tree/gb-beagleplay). booted into the kernel. but I am getting `Got Unknown Frame 65`  when loading the driver, which pr
the driver, which probably means the UART i am connected to is not the correct one.

Ok, so it seems the driver is actually working. It's just that the upstream greybus cannot parse the manifest that bcf sends. I guess it is due to the extensions to manifest made for mikrobus. But the
or mikrobus. But the svc interactions work.

first levels of comments https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commits/gb-beagleplay
1. subject line: follow the convention of the files being touched - do git log --oneline file_name to see convention
2

to see convention
2. commit message should have more detailed commit message to explain to the reviewer why the change is needed etc.. 
3. the sequence of patches should be:
Device tree binding yaml

e tree binding yaml binding
driver changes
dts update
https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/d4ebd7c0aacb5db2a5827eea1ddbc95894cdf87e should be rolled up with the driver patch
I doubt https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/8b9326ec614d3d1ce6a2369b376b565aca66b8d7 is going to fly upstream. Device tree must describe hardware.
The name should be descriptive or should it not be added to the device tree? I picked it up from ti kernel device tree.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JrwZ4xLBU38&list=PLbzoR-pLrL6pY8a8zSKRC6-AihFrruOkq&index=15 watch this video

https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/237b8f449dd85bd821f4fd1f136720269743a251#diff-8dba146cc2d0e7c65771c9ce939c75b9dc568361253e8e0837b525eb50848355R5 -> You need to add Copyright (C) 2023  Beagle
ght (C) 2023  BeagleBoard.org Foundation -> @rcn-ee / @JKridner  comment on exact beagleboard.org foundation license to add
https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/237b8f449dd85bd821f4fd1f136720269743a251#diff-8dba146cc2d0e7c65771c9ce939c75b9dc568361253e8e0837b525eb50848355R242 no C++ comments in code
TI tree does'nt support mikrobus ðŸ˜‰ - it was probably picked up from beagle kernel ðŸ™‚
https://gist.github.com/nmenon/bf15fc8c5df7d3380a71454e9ad37b58 -> output of kpv -C -V -L -n 3
all the patches should pass the standard static checkers which is what kernel_patch_verify runs.. so your series is not ready for submission upstream ðŸ˜¦
since you are working with linux-next https://gist.github.com/nmenon/bf15fc8c5df7d3380a71454e9ad37b58#file-kpv-c-v-l-n-3-L184 -> warnings that is coming in from other files, I'd ignore
nore
Yes. I was fixing those one by one after having run them locally. I will push to the branch once they are fixed.
ok, good.
I was more concerned about the fact that without mikrobus in upstream, the driver cannot be used with any actual bcf node.
That  is how we build a system up -> this needs to be clearly explained to folks what are these changes meant to bring in and why. how we are building the stack up. this is foundational layer.
ional layer.
So, cover-letter and commit message of the patch will need to be descriptive enough to explain. device tree binding has to be rather very strong to get past Rob/Krystoff/Connor
Yeah, I definitely need to add that. I didn't think mikrobus would be needed if I am not actually using mikrobus.

yeah - keep in mind that the people who  will review have no idea what beagleplay is. or  cc1352 is. unless they are convinced this is benefitting large userbase, it is a tough sell -> it is branded n
l -> it is branded narrowly as beagleplay greybus extension.. which makes it harder to accept
Hmm. I have actually considered branding it as a generic greybus extension when we have SVC in a different co-processor with UART between them. The only device I currently know of which falls in this
which falls in this is beagleplay though.
The SVC running code simply needs to be connected with UART, not even be in the same pcb if you really want to stretch it.

you have to sell it's potential to a wider base than beagleplay - that is key. and have documentation to explain how people can use it beyond beagleplay. that makes it more interesting to folks to rev
ting to folks to review and accept.
Thanks. Will definitely look into that.
i am not entirely sure where the staging drivers' device tree bindings go.. hmm..
funny to see greybus sitting in staging area after all these years!
given an option, i might have extended actual non-staging virtio framework instead..
sorry, did'nt mean to diminish your work.. just thinking aloud.. looking at this  for the first time.
Sure. What did you mean by extending virtio framework? It seems interesting.
but yeah - in the cover-letter it will need to explain why existing virtio or other similar frameworks were not chosen and why grey-bus was the logical answer..
https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/next/driver-api/virtio/virtio.html
anyways, thanks for putting the branch together.. it is much easier to see what is going on.. i gotta go now, kids are waking up.. gotta feed the little monsters ðŸ˜‰
Sure. Thanks for all your help. Will keep working on this in my free time.
np

@Nishanth Menon I have tried writing a dt schema: https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/b8ef3d190256623426dd7913cb8d9c636bd14992. It doesn't seem to throw any eroros on running `make dt_binding_ch
`make dt_binding_check DT_SCHEMA_FILES=beaglecc1352.yaml -j12` but well, I have no idea if it is what is expected.

```
subject line: follow the convention of the files being touched - do git log --oneline file_name to see convention
```
Which commit are you referring to? The gb-beagleplay commit touches the Makefi
t touches the Makefile, KConfig and gb-beagleplay. Should it instead say `greybus: gb-beagleplay:`?
Did u run kpv? It takes care of the checks. Directory path looks wrong
Compatible. You just have one item. So just const: beagle, cc1352
Also add an example dts to show. The main fight here is to explain why is this hardware definition

As I said I want cc'ed on patches themselves, so wasn't able to give exact comments. But if you did do what I said on the files, you should see the pattern. The dts patch for example was definitely wr
le was definitely wrong.
It should not go under `serial`?
@Nishanth Menon Also, should I really cc lkml on all the patches even though I am sending to greybus mailing list and Ccing device tree ml?
Yes
scripts/get_maintainers.pl will tell u the same thing
@Nishanth Menon I think `s/dev_warn/dev_warn_ratelimited` means substituting (at least in vimspeak)?
yup
Ok. I thought the ratelimit comment was about general ratelimiting and not logging.
his comment specifically was on dev_warn
Yeah. My mistake. I was't really aware about the ratelimited versions of logging to it never crossed my mind.
I think the most troublesome one is https://lore.kernel.org/all/937ea540-09e1-65f2-7165-662bbee2542b@kernel.org/
I dont see any other greybus bindings in Documentation/device-tree/ ... so makes this a big challenge
Does a binding which resides in childnode (beaglecc1352 in our case) need to define the properties of the main device or parent (main_uart6)?

Are there maybe any bindings that just introduce a compatible string and nothing more? Maybe that would be a good place to start? 
Greybus is now in stable, so it should at least be possible to add gr
e possible to add greybus bindings, if a bit hard

no - wl1807 binding is it's own yaml file.

What we could claim is 1352 as a binding..
so greybus is just the bus protocol it uses, but the main thing is dt describes how 1352 device integrates. NOTE: this might conflict with other approaches..
Yes, it does seem like claiming it 1352 binding might end up being what needs to be done. I would still ask around in the patch thread to see if there are any better approaches.
I'm moving the ideas page for next year... help reviewing and editing appreciated: https://bbb.io/gsocideas
I want to contribute to gsoc can anyone suggest a good repo in beagle board before proposing any idea my language is javascript.
Sorry if this question is very basic.
Actually I was able to find project ideas but I need to submit some initial PRs before giving gsoc proposal for which I need to find initial repository to contribute.
Fun opps on mainline (6.6-rc1) ```[   12.687223] gb_beagleplay serial0-0: Using baudrate 115200```
https://git.beagleboard.org/RobertCNelson/arm64-multiplatform/-/tree/v6.6.x-arm64-k3/patches/gb-beagleplay might be behind...

Hmm. The patch 3 seems to be missing: https://github.com/Ayush1325/linux/commit/63fe6da2be2472133565de8f23ef92d710eb5d84. I also have more NULL checks since that patch. I will check out if I can repro
k out if I can reproduce it on my local tree.
Oh patch 3 got moved into the DT changes repo..
Yeah. It will stay on 3 patches from now (as far as I can tell).
https://git.beagleboard.org/beagleboard/BeagleBoard-DeviceTrees/-/blob/v6.6.x/src/arm64/k3-am625-beagleplay.dts
I had other DT changes, it was easier the changing patch 3 again and again
Sure. the mainline and beagle kernel dt are different so I am not sure if you could directly apply the patch anyway. Although the dt name will change again from all the feedback I have got.
have got.
So how much of CC1352 do I need to describe in dtbindings? The Kernel docs say you should describe the complete device so I guess I should use the complete binding from zephyr/dts (modified for linux

(modified for linux since the zephyr dt schema seems quite different), and define cc1352 as an soc. 
Also should it be `ti,cc1352` or `beagle,cc1352`?
@JKridner @Nishanth Menon As outlined in the mailing list by Jason (https://lists.linaro.org/archives/list/greybus-dev@lists.linaro.org/message/ZLH5INCQPV3YEYMVCW4V2R5CDMHFQOOA/), I think branding it

I think branding it as BeagleConnect would be a good option. 
This would mean having bindings in `Documentation/devicetree/bindings/firmware/beagle,beagleconnect.yaml` and allow future additions as Be
ture additions as BeagleConnect instead of being tied to beagleplay. The driver can be renamed as `gb-beagleconnect`.
dt bindings needs to be hardware

The dt bindings under `Documentation/devicetree/bindings/firmware/` seem to be more related to firmware running on top of soc than the device itself. Like `amlogic,meson-gxbb-sm.yaml` seems to be used

ml` seems to be used to identify `Amlogic Secure Monitor (SM)` and has a single required compatibilty or `nvidia,tegra186-bpmp.yaml` for BPMP processor in nvidia gpus.
We can describe cc1352 as the be
ibe cc1352 as the beagleconnect or svc processor in case of beagleplay device rather than any generic cc1352.
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/arch/arm64/boot/dts/nvidia/tegra194.dtsi#n1723 for example is tied to a specific hardware

you need to describe the hardware and then properties or subnodes (such as links) OR you will need to go via actual h/w call path - such as smc (secure monitor call) https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/lin
rnel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/arch/arm64/boot/dts/freescale/imx8ulp.dtsi#n169
simplest will be to link it as cc1352 and then extend the description as a link property
it will fly better with the maintainers as "generic" devices are strictly frowned upon
PHandle, not literally links property
@Nishanth Menon Should I place cc1352 bindings under `soc/ti`? or maybe create a new folder for `beagle`?
typically we dont. soc/ti are for description of the entire SoC. wllink power ICs etc go their specific folders
Hmm. Won't we have to categorize CC1352 as an SoC? Although I guess categorizing it as SoC would mean having to describe the complete hardware (even the parts not being used) according to docs.
ding to docs.

@Nishanth Menon What resources would need to be added to the dt bindings?  Krzysztof mentioned this: "By resources I mean whatever is needed to power it up and operate, e.g. clocks, supplies, reset li
, supplies, reset lines.". But well, I am not sure if anything other than compatible is needed for cc1352p7 as an mcu
Also, it was suggested to use `ti,cc1352p7` as the device name. Since this is not a full SoC (I think?), it should probably go into `arm` There is a `arm/ti` folder as well so should it be put there?
ld it be put there?
You will need things like reset lines etc.
I thought I explained previously
Reset lines refers to RESET_IN in data sheet right?
Yes. There will be clocks etc
Look at a peripheral on uart as an example

You mentioned that they go to their specific folders, but well, I am not sure if `cc1352p7` is a net mcu or a generic arm mcu. And there are other `cc1352p*` and `cc1352r*`, so not sure if that change
sure if that changes anything.
You need to look at it as a peripheral, not a processor view
think that cc1352p7 is not programmable. it is a ROMed peripheral
now, what does cc1352p7 need to talk to SoC from SoC's perspective - remember the description is agnostic of beagleplay. even iMX8 should be able to interface with it
it has a clock, reset lines, may be power supplies..
you would start from https://www.ti.com/product/CC1352P7
Thanks, will start there
supplies, reset, osc clock - correct?
DT is hardware description -> so using Documentation/devicetree/bindings/net/wireless/ti,wlcore.yaml as an example..
See these examples: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/devicetree/bindings/net/wireless/ti%2Cwlcore.yaml - it can interface with mmc, spi among other options..
Rather curious case here though - if cc1352p7 is a peripheral - it has a different dt view compared to zephyr trying to describe cc1352p7 in device tree, where it is the processor view!
view!

eplay.dts#L874). I referred to design docs (https://docs.beagleboard.org/latest/boards/beagleplay/03-design.html) for connections. Should I send a new patch or wait for feedback on `gb-beagleplay` dri
`gb-beagleplay` driver?

Welcome @Adarsh !  Please feel encouraged to share more about yourself and your interests. Visiting the https://bbb.io/gsocideas page might provide inspiration. Contributing to open source is very muc
n source is very much about building community--understanding problems faced by community members and matching your skills to help solve those problems.
This 'all-hands office hour' is all about knowing there will be people on-line and interacting on GSoC topics, so please look to spend this hour with us every week and get to know what is going on in
what is going on in our community.
don't hesitate to check out the other channels and see what topics are common. poking around on the forum is good.

also, please don't hesitate to speak your mind. if you get some impression, please share it with openness and compassion. we try to always be improving and know some things can be intimidating or feel
intimidating or feel uncomfortable.
@lorforlinux I want to get fixes on https://bbb.io/gsocideas up *fast*. What do we need to sync here on?
if you aren't doing something right away, I might go ahead and just push my approach.
I think that's a great idea @JKridner the build may take a lot of CI time though.
perhaps. a lot of time on the beagle kernel is spent building a *huge* set of drivers.
if we minimize the drivers, the build time can probably be pretty small.
We can also build kernel modules using the Beagle pre-built kernel and then just run the kernel in `qemu`. That might save time and be a more fruitful test.
